title: What are the similarities and differences between social science, humanities, and natural sciences? - Quora

response.answer_text: In very simple terms — Social Science — studies social Institutions and structures by using the quantitative methods of social statistics. It can study small groups, but it often involves statistics involving thousands, millions or hundreds of millions of people. It then forms theories from the actual social statistics. (Subjective level: 50%)Humanities — studies the Arts, including the Fine Arts, the Performing Arts, Literature, Poetry, Drama, Theater, Music, Dance, Acting, Ethics, Politics, Public Speaking, Rhetoric, History, and so on. (Subjective level: 90%)Natural Science — studies Nature, including Mathematics, Logic, Physics, Astronomy, Geology, Geography, Oceanography, Chemistry, Botany, Biology, Zoology, Anatomy, Psychology, (Subjective level: 10%)Those are the simplest terms that I see. The main similarities are that: (1) they are all college courses; (2) they are all professions; and (3) each segment can require a full career. The differences are obvious from these simplest of definitions. Especially the Subjective level, i.e. the amount of Original Thinking permitted for each discipline. The Subjective level is least for the Natural Sciences because all of their objects are given to our five senses. Everybody can see, hear, touch, smell and taste these objects — even animals can. There is no originality that humans can add to them; so the only Subjectivity allowed is New Technology (e.g. a telescope, a microscope, an electroscope, a computer, etc.). Yet most of Natural Science is a careful, quiet exploration of Nature herself. The New Technology is useful only if it helps in that exploration. The Subjective level is median for Social Sciences, because what do you do with all those social statistics? You put them in many fancy charts, but so what? Somebody must come up with a Theory to propose interpretations of the statistics. The statistics are what they are — given by reality — this is 50% of the Science. But the other 50% is interpretation. The Subjective level is highest for the Humanities. Originality — something new and different — Creativity is the highest value! The past is useful only as something else to surpass. Always changing — Opinion matters — Art Criticism is a plausible career in itself. Certainty is fleeting in this Department. Those are the simplest terms that I see.

The Humanities makes a study of human existence via philosophy, art, literatures, etc. Natural sciences study the natural world via physics, mathematics, chemistry, biology and related areas of study that can be measured. Social “science” is a lot a nonsense made up by people who cannot work in the other two categories.
